keyTakeAways: Bear attacks in Japan have increased significantly, with over 100 injuries and seven deaths reported in 2025 — the highest number since 2006.
A 32-year-old runner from Auckland, New Zealand, Billy Halloran, was attacked by two Asiatic black bears during a routine run in Myoko, Japan.
The bear attacked Halloran, biting off a piece of his arm and injuring his leg, leading to three surgeries, including a hip graft and metal plates in his arm.
Experts attribute the rise in bear attacks to climate change disrupting natural food sources, prompting bears to venture into urban and suburban areas.
The Japanese government has announced tougher measures to control bear populations in response to the escalating threats.
Residents are taking precautions such as carrying bells or playing loud music to deter bears.
Halloran plans to return to running in the woods despite trauma and ongoing recovery, and expresses gratitude for community support.
The incident reflects a growing global concern about wildlife-human conflict due to climate change and habitat disruption.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Billy Halloran, a 32-year-old runner from Auckland, New Zealand, was attacked by two Asiatic black bears during a routine run in Myoko, Japan. The attack resulted in severe injuries, including a bitten-off piece of his arm and claw punctures to his leg, requiring three surgeries. This incident occurred amid a surge in bear attacks across Japan — over 100 injuries and seven deaths in 2025 — attributed to climate change disrupting bears' traditional food sources and forcing them into human habitats. The Japanese government has responded by announcing tougher measures to control bear populations. Halloran, though traumatized and recovering physically and mentally, remains determined to return to running in nature, highlighting both the personal risks and the broader societal challenge of human-wildlife conflict in a changing climate.
